title: The Static Site Paradox
dot:
digraph PersonalWebsites{rankdir=TB;node[shape=box];mainIdea[label="Making the Web More Accessible" shape=ellipse];website1[label="Complex CMS (PHP)
- Requires web server
- Multiple workers
- Redis cache
- SQL database
- Single Page Application (SPA)
- JSON content rehydration" shape=box];website2[label="Static HTML/CSS
- No JavaScript
- Simple hosting" shape=box];normalUsers[label="Normal Users
- Generally use complex solutions
- Stuck with overcomplicated options" shape=box];softwareEngineers[label="Professional Engineers
- Few use static sites
- Prefer complex solutions due to ease of setup" shape=box];challenges[label="Challenges for Normal Users:
1. Buy a domain
2. Find a hosting platform
3. Configure DNS
4. Find an SSG
5. Learn deployment pipeline" shape=box];solutions[label="Call to Action:
- Simplify web development
- Make simple things easy
- Encourage diversity in web creation" shape=box];mainIdea->website1;mainIdea->website2;mainIdea->normalUsers;mainIdea->softwareEngineers; normalUsers->website1;softwareEngineers->website2;normalUsers->challenges;softwareEngineers->challenges;mainIdea->solutions;}

title: An illustrated proof of the CAP theorem (2018)
dot:
digraph CAP_Theorem{graph[fontname="Helvetica,arial,sans-serif", fontcolor="black", fontsize=12, tooltip="CAP Theorem Visualization", labelloc="t", labeljust="c", bgcolor="white"];node[shape=ellipse, fontname="Helvetica,arial,sans-serif", fontcolor="black", fontsize=12, style=filled, fillcolor="lightgray"];edge[fontname="Helvetica,arial,sans-serif", fontcolor="black", fontsize=10];CAP[label="CAP Theorem

In a distributed system, you can have at most two of the following properties:", shape=box, fillcolor="lightyellow", style="filled, rounded"];Consistency[label="Consistency
Every read receives the most recent write or an error."];Availability[label="Availability
Every request receives a (non-error) response, without guarantee that it contains the most recent write."];PartitionTolerance[label="Partition Tolerance
The system continues to operate despite arbitrary partitioning of the network."];CAP->Consistency;CAP->Availability;CAP->PartitionTolerance;DistributedSystem[label="Distributed System
Multiple servers coordinating to manage data and services.", shape=box, fillcolor="lightblue"];CAP->DistributedSystem[label="applies to"];GilbertLynch[label="Gilbert and Lynch's Proof
It is impossible to achieve consistency, availability, and partition tolerance simultaneously."];CAP->GilbertLynch;ExampleSystem[label="Example System
Two servers ($G_1$, $G_2$) tracking variable $v$.
Communicate with clients.", shape=box, fillcolor="lightcoral"];DistributedSystem->ExampleSystem[label="example of"];ProofStep1[label="Partition the system.
$G_1$ and $G_2$ cannot communicate."];ProofStep2[label="Client writes $v_1$ to $G_1$.
$G_1$ responds (availability),
but cannot replicate to $G_2$."];ProofStep3[label="Client reads from $G_2$.
$G_2$ responds with stale $v_0$."];ProofStep4[label="Inconsistency detected.
$G_2$ returns stale value despite
client having written $v_1$ to $G_1$."];GilbertLynch->ProofStep1[label="Step 1"];GilbertLynch->ProofStep2[label="Step 2"];GilbertLynch->ProofStep3[label="Step 3"];GilbertLynch->ProofStep4[label="Step 4"];ProofStep1->ProofStep2;ProofStep2->ProofStep3;ProofStep3->ProofStep4;}
